summary: Frank Fiorini was an arms buyer in Miami who was under investigation for possible Registration Act violations in 1959. A classified message from the Director to Santiago de Cuba instructed the base to deal with Fiorini under consular cover without making any commitments that might be construed as approval of his activities. He is mentioned in a Latin America Division (LAD) report summarizing a task force investigation into possible Cuban complicity in the John F. Kennedy assassination, reviewing Agency operations against Cuba from 1960 to 1965 and finding no definitive proof of Cuban involvement. He is also mentioned in a dispatch detailing JMWAVE's relationship with AMCARBON-1, a media contact at the Miami Herald, outlining how he provides operational support, intelligence, and serves as a propaganda outlet while ensuring the security of JMWAVE operations. He is also mentioned in a transcript of a hearing with Alfred J. Sarno regarding the CIA's AMUTS program, which involved Cuban exiles collecting intelligence on Cuba, debriefing refugees, and providing personnel for operations; the transcript details the structure, activities, and personnel of the AMUTS program, including its relationship with the Miami station and the FBI. Finally, he is mentioned in a memorandum detailing the planned phase-out of the CIA's operational relationship with Manuel ARTINE Buesa's autonomous group, including discussions about demobilization support, weapons disposition, and preventing regional instability.
significance: Frank Fiorini's significance in the JFK assassination context is related to the investigation into possible Cuban complicity. He was an arms buyer in Miami, and the investigation into his activities may have been relevant to understanding the broader network of individuals and organizations involved in anti-Castro activities and potential connections to the assassination.
